paper_metadata.title: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Cooperative Deployment of a Generalized, Archaeology-Specific Field Data Collection System
paper_metadata.book_title: Mobilizing the Past for a Digital Future: The Potential of Digital Archaeology
paper_metadata.publisher: The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota
paper_metadata.notes: 58-page book chapter describing FAIMS Mobile deployment across three archaeological projects (Boncuklu Turkey, Malawi palaeoanthropology, Peru survey). Published in open-access edited volume.

orcid_coverage.notes: No ORCIDs present. ORCID adoption in HASS was minimal in 2016 (ORCID launched 2012, academic adoption slow). Not expected for book chapter from regional academic press.

software_pids.description: Field data collection system for archaeology
software_pids.notes: FAIMS project website URL provided but no GitHub repository or archival DOI mentioned in 2016 chapter (contrast with Ballsun-Stanton 2018 SoftwareX which has 6 GitHub repos)

pid_graph_summary.notes: Zero PID connectivity. Book chapter has ISBN (book-level) and institutional repository URLs but no chapter DOI. No author ORCIDs, no dataset PIDs, no software PIDs (URL only). Reflects 2016 HASS infrastructure baseline before widespread PID adoption.

funding.funder_name: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR)
funding.verbatim_text: The FAIMS project was funded during 2012–2013 by the National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043)
from 2014 to 2016 by the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Equipment, Infrastructure, and Facilities (LIEF) program (LE140100151)
funding.notes: AUD $945,000 total ARC funding plus university matching contributions (approximately 1/3 to 1/2 additional). Matching grant requiring partner co-investment.

funding.verbatim_text: The University of New South Wales (2012–2014)... have offered the project a home and made significant cash and in-kind contributions to the LIEF (which is a matching grant).
funding.notes: Host institution with cash and in-kind contributions as LIEF matching partner

funding.verbatim_text: Macquarie University (2015–present) have offered the project a home and made significant cash and in-kind contributions to the LIEF
funding.notes: Host institution from 2015. In-kind contributions estimated at ~$100,000/year (academic staff time). Cash contributions as LIEF matching partner.

funding.verbatim_text: the National Endowment for the Humanities funded "Mobilizing the Past" workshop
funding.notes: Funded workshop that led to this edited volume

fair_assessment.rationale: No data availability statement expected for 2016 book chapter describing software deployment. Chapter mentions supplementary materials (customized modules) but access not specified. Data sharing norms for HASS book chapters minimal in 2016.

data_availability.notes: Book chapter focuses on software deployment process, not data. Mentions 'Supplementary Material 1: Fairbairn: Boncuklu Case' but location/access not specified. Book published open-access (CC-BY-4.0) but supplementary materials access unclear.

repositories.description: FAIMS Mobile 2.0 field data collection system

computational_reproducibility.rationale: Chapter describes software deployment but provides only project website URL, not source code repositories. FAIMS is mentioned as open-source but no GitHub/repository links provided in 2016 chapter. Software availability documented in later publications (Ballsun-Stanton 2018 provides 6 GitHub repos). Reflects 2016 norms - code sharing increasing but not yet standard for book chapters.

environment_specification.notes: No environment specification. Chapter describes Android tablets (Nexus 7, Nexus 9) and FAIMS 2.0 software but no dependency specifications.

analysis_transparency.notes: Chapter provides extensive narrative description of deployment process, design decisions, lessons learned. Focuses on software engineering and co-design methodology rather than computational analysis.

fair_assessment.rationale: Software URL provided but no repository links, no archival DOI, no version control metadata. FAIR assessment not applicable for 2016 book chapter (predates widespread FAIR4RS adoption). Software availability improved in later publications (2018 SoftwareX provides comprehensive repository links).

code_availability.notes: 2016 chapter mentions FAIMS software and describes deployments but does not provide code repositories or detailed technical documentation. Project website URL given for more information. Represents pre-FAIR era software documentation practices. Contrast with 2018 SoftwareX publication which provides 6 GitHub repositories, comprehensive documentation, and satisfies FAIR4RS principles.

author_contributions.notes: No author contribution statement. Not standard for book chapters in 2016. CReDIT taxonomy gaining adoption in journals (Nature began requiring 2014) but not yet standard for edited volumes.

conflicts_of_interest.notes: No competing interests statement. Not standard for book chapters in 2016.

ethics_approval.notes: No ethics statement. Chapter describes software deployment (no human/animal subjects research in this chapter). The archaeological projects described (Boncuklu, Malawi, Peru) would have required permits but not discussed here.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Chapter focuses on software deployment process. The three archaeological projects described (Boncuklu excavation Turkey, Malawi palaeoanthropology, Peru survey) would have required permits from respective national authorities but not discussed in this chapter (focus is on software, not fieldwork ethics).

preregistration.notes: No preregistration. Not applicable for software deployment case study. Preregistration adoption minimal in HASS in 2016 (growing in psychology but not yet in archaeology).

materials.notes: Mentioned in text as containing 'three customized modules' but no access information or repository link provided

supplementary_materials.notes: Supplementary materials mentioned but access information not provided. Common for 2016 book chapters - supplementary materials often provided to editors but not systematically archived/linked.

references_completeness.notes: References section present (pages 55-58). Formal assessment deferred. DOI usage likely lower than 2023 papers given 2016 publication date.

primary_gaps: No data repository or availability statement
No code repository links (project URL only)
Supplementary materials mentioned but access unclear
strengths: Chapter archived in institutional repository (UWM Digital Commons)
Project website provided for software information
Extensive narrative documentation of deployment process
fair_assessment.notes: Zero FAIR score reflects 2016 book chapter baseline before widespread PID adoption and FAIR principles. Published pre-FAIR Guidelines (Wilkinson 2016) and pre-FAIR4RS (Chue Hong 2022). Represents transition era: open-access publishing adopted (CC-BY-4.0), code sharing emerging (project website), but persistent identifiers and structured metadata not yet standard. Institutional repository deposit (UWM Digital Commons) provides some preservation but no DOI minting. Software documentation improved dramatically by 2018 (Ballsun-Stanton SoftwareX: 13/15 FAIR).

extraction_notes: 58-page book chapter from regional academic press (University of North Dakota Digital Press)
Published 2016 - pre-FAIR Guidelines (Wilkinson 2016 published same year), pre-widespread PID adoption
Comprehensive funding acknowledgements: 2 major grants (NeCTAR RT043 2012-2013, ARC LIEF LE140100151 2014-2016, AUD $945K+ matching)
No chapter DOI (book ISBN only) - typical for regional academic press 2016
No ORCIDs (ORCID adoption minimal in HASS 2016, ~5% baseline)
Software URL provided but no GitHub repos (contrast 2018 SoftwareX: 6 repos)
Supplementary materials mentioned but access unclear - pre-structured supplementary material practices
Zero PID connectivity (0/6) - reflects 2016 HASS baseline
Historical comparison valuable: Shows infrastructure evolution 2016→2018→2024
Same software (FAIMS) documented across 2016 chapter (0/15 FAIR) and 2018 SoftwareX (13/15 FAIR) - shows rapid infrastructure improvement
Book chapter format has different norms than journal articles (no data/code statements expected 2016)
